an7.72:4.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
an7.72:4.3: While walking along the road, at a certain spot he saw a bonfire burning, blazing and glowing.
an7.72:4.4: Seeing this he left the road, sat at the root of a tree on an indicated seat,
an7.72:4.6: “Mendicants, do you see that bonfire burning, blazing, and glowing?”
an7.72:5.1: “What do you think, mendicants, which is better?
an7.72:5.2: To sit or lie down embracing that bonfire? Or to sit or lie down embracing a girl of the aristocrats or brahmins or householders with soft and tender hands and feet?”
an7.72:5.4: to sit or lie down embracing a girl of the aristocrats or brahmins or householders with soft and tender hands and feet. For it would be painful to sit or lie down embracing that bonfire.”
an7.72:6.1: “I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you! It would be better for that unethical man—of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, secretive, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner, though claiming to be one, rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved—to sit or lie down embracing that bonfire.
an7.72:6.3: Because that might result in death or deadly pain. But when his body breaks up, after death, it would not cause him to be reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an7.72:7.1: But when such an unethical man
an7.72:7.2: sits or lies down embracing a girl of the aristocrats or brahmins or householders with soft and tender hands and feet, that brings him lasting harm and suffering. When his body breaks up, after death, he’s reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an7.72:8.1: What do you think, mendicants, which is better?
an7.72:8.2: To have a strong man twist a tough horse-hair rope around both shins and tighten it
an7.72:8.3: so that it cut through your outer skin, inner skin, flesh, sinews, and bones, until it reached your marrow and stayed pressing there? Or to consent to propertied aristocrats or brahmins or householders bowing down to you?

an7.72:8.6: until it reached the marrow and stayed pressing there.”

an7.72:20.1: So you should train like this:
an7.72:20.2: ‘Our use of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick shall be of great fruit and benefit for those who offered them. And our going forth will not be barren, but fruitful and fertile.’
an7.72:20.4: Considering your own good, mendicants, is quite enough for you to diligently perfect yourselves.
an7.72:20.5: Considering the good of others is quite enough for you to diligently perfect yourselves.
an7.72:20.6: Considering the good of both is quite enough for you to diligently perfect yourselves.”
an7.72:21.1: This is what the Buddha said.
an7.72:21.2: And while this discourse was being spoken, sixty monks spewed hot blood from their mouths.
an7.72:21.3: Sixty mendicants abandoned the training and returned to a lesser life, saying:
an7.72:21.4: ‘It’s too hard, Blessed One! It’s just too hard!”
an7.72:21.5: And sixty monks were freed from defilements without grasping.
